doc.field: Sneak preview of so far unpublished CDU/CSU election paper

The governing CDU/CSU parties apparently came out strongly in favour of cutting down on immigration, according to a so far unpublished party paper. According to the newspaper RHEINISCHE POST, the paper stated that whoever wanted more people to enter and settle in our densely populated country, would put internal stability and peace at risk. Illegal immigrants should only receive the bare minimum, according to the report. The paper apparently also was against dual citizenship. If someone wanted to take out German citizenship, they would have to give up their former one
Mr Schaeuble thinks he's up to becoming Chancellor Kohl's successor

Head of the CDU/CSU parliamentary group Schaeuble refuted speculations he would not be available as successor to Chancellor Helmut Kohl any more. In an interview with the news magazine DER SPIEGEL, Mr Schaeuble said that he would be up to the job, in spite of being a paraplegic. Previously his wife Ingeborg had remarked in an interview that she had some doubts if the German public would accept a Chancellor in a wheelchair, sparking the current debate.

Federal Health Minister Seehofer got his way as far as one important item in the row about inflated dental fees was concerned. The Dentists' Association declared, after Mr Seehofer had leaned on them, that they were prepared to inform their members about the rules on ceilings for fees. They are now complying with an obligation Mr Seehofer already had stipulated as early as at the beginning of June, which - according to the minister - was important for the patients, some of whom had almost lost all faith in the system.

If the SPD's candidate becomes Chancellor in the upcoming elections, the Greens will be the first Mr Schroeder will want to talk to about forming a coalition government. Only in case they could not come to an agreement, would he start talking to the CDU/CSU parties straight away. As he reiterated from his holiday home on the island of Borkum/North Sea, he would rather deal with Defence Minister Ruehe than head of the CDU/CSU parliamentary group Schaeuble - if there was to be a big coalition (between SPD and CDU/CSU).

Federal Finance Minister Waigel gave the green light to make the first Euro coins at the Bavarian Mint in Munich. They are not meant for public use, however, they only serve to check out the machines. This autumn (fall) they will do the real thing, and mint 1 and 20 Cent as well 1 Euro coins. The coins will be put into circulation in 2002
2 percent of Bavaria's population on social welfare benefit

Last year approximately 2 percent of Bavaria's population drew a social welfare benefit, a total of 252,000 to be exact (7.8% up on the previous year). According to the State Statistics Office more than half of the beneficiaries were female, including solo mothers. About 60% of the beneficiaries were of working age (between 15 and 65 years old). The social welfare benefit for approximately 134,000 households amounted to about 774 marks per month, on average.
Another accident involving an ICE high-speed train

Approximately two months after the tragic crash of an ICE high-speed train at Eschede there was more of the same: South of Peine/Lower Saxony a train hit a car on a level crossing killing the 23-year old driver instantly. Police and railways staff take it that the driver had tried to zigzag his way around the closed barrier arms
